title.narrative: Training of Youth Peer Educators on Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights in Mozambique (PET in SRHR)

description.narrative:
The proposed project must contribute to the following ++objective++:
- Universal access to sexual and reproductive health and rights (SDG 3 and 5).
The proposed project must contribute to at least one of the following ++long-term impacts++:
- More respect for the sexual and reproductive rights of groups who are currently denied these rights; - Better public and private health care for family planning, pregnancies and childbirth, including safe abortions; and/or - Better information and greater freedom of choice for young people about their sexuality.
The following ++medium-term impact++ will contribute to this:
- Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable (SDG 17); - Organisations key to (sectoral) inclusive development of partner countries are strengthened by inflow of enhanced workforce.
This will be achieved by the following ++outcome++:
- Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs and aiming at inclusiveness.
++Outputs++:
- Staff of CDD and 45 youth leaders improved their Knowledge and training skills in SRHR. - CDD youth leadership training module on SRHR developed, tested and ready for use in training young girls and boys during summer school. - A network of youth leaders in SRHR formed and used CDD platform to engage young girls an boys on SRHR issues. - 45 youth peer education trainers organized leadership change making interventions or outreach services.
​

This project seeks to put youth leadership at the centre of actions to address sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR) challenges in Mozambique. CDD is implementing the 2-year project (January 2020-June 2021) in collaboration with EUR-ISS and the African Governance Institute (AFRIGI), both in the Netherlands. Fifteen CDD staff and its associates are being trained to become Master Trainers (MTs) in SRHR. Nine training modules are being developed to enable MTs for Peer Education Training (PET) in SRHR. MTs will cascade their knowledge to 45 young men and women representing four principal forms of clinical & non-clinical SRHR services in Mozambique: (i) Health care providers; (ii) Justice law and order sector (JLOS); (iii) NGOs & CBOs staff that work with vulnerable and marginalised groups and; (iv) Educational institutions that facilitate vocational/technical skills training. The PET focuses on non-clinical SRHR services such as (i) mobilization of young people to use SRHR services; (ii) provision of information, education, and communication (IEC) for behavioural change on SRHR; (iii) life skills development such as confidence building, assertiveness and negotiation skills for safe sex; (iv) economic empowerment and livelihoods; (v) social action to reduce sexual and gender based violence; and (vi) creating opportunities for young people to network and collaborate on SRHR issues. The training programme provides space for participants to design and implement ‘peer educators leadership change-making projects’ on specific SRHR issues in the country. The training, coaching and mentoring of 45 peer educators are organised in three provincial centres Manica, Nampula and Maputo. It is expected that also after the PET project is completed 45 peer-educators would continue reaching out to young men and women at their work and in communities of practice across the country in the next couple of years, bringing the total estimated number of project beneficiaries to 5000.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the Grant Obligations and Conditions, the obligatory dates for submission of the annual/additional reports are mentioned. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative:
In this section (maximum 1000 words), please
**For TMT+:**
Comment to what extent the outputs have been achieved. Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
Training modules on YSRHR for peer educators developed, tested and ready for use in summer school

description.narrative: CDD Youth leadership training module on YSRHR developed, tested and ready for use in training male and female youth during summer school.

comment.narrative: Availability of SRHR training modules to be used to cascade training to 5000 male and female youth.

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

comment.narrative:
45 employees/ associates of CDD successfully completed trainers course on YPET in SRHR (at least 50% are women) and received certificate in youth leadership and (peer) educators in SRHR.
CDD staff use their new skills to organize and deliver YSRHR modules in the summer school.
Means of verification: CDD summer school reports.

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 15 private organizations strengthened by individual and/or group training.

title.narrative: B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative:
45 YPEs cascaded YSRHR to 1000 youth and others in their workplaces and community of practice.
45 YPE have applied their knowledge and skills that have enabled at least 1000 male and female youth to protect themselves from STIs.
45 YPEs have applied their leadership skills in SRHR through 'the leadership change making projects'.

title.narrative: B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women

comment.narrative:
50% of scholarship for CDD trainees in the summer school awarded to women.
22 women graduated from the TMT.

title.narrative: B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 80% trainees stated that they can communicate effectively with peers (on YSRHR (reproductive health; gender inclusiveness; livelihood empowerment; sexual violence, etc.)).

title.narrative: B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction

comment.narrative: At least 50% of the YPEs are applying their new skills in workplaces and communities.

title.narrative: CDD staff and strainers organised youth summer school on SRHR to cascade the training to 105 young girls and boys yearly.

comment.narrative:
- CDD staff and trainers organized youth summer school on SRHR to cascade the training to 105young girls and boys yearly.
- 100% of the participants in the summer school complete the training

title.narrative: Youth peer education trainers organised leadership change making interventions or outreach services

comment.narrative: 45 youth peer educators develop change making YSRHR projects on a range of issues - like HIV/AIDS awareness, Advocacy campaigns on FGM, STIs, early Child marriage and pregnancy, etc.

title.narrative: A SRHR platform with youth peer educators established

comment.narrative:
A network of 60 youth leaders in SRHR formed and used CDD platform to engage young girls and boys on SRHR issues.
45 youth leaders/activists become knowledgeable in youth SRHR issues and used CDD platform to interact with peers.
3 CDD staff trained to be support youth leaders in SRHR as mentors.
An MoU signed between CDD and Youth Trainers to provide training during the summer school.

title.narrative: Training needs assessment

comment.narrative:
Appraisal of the training needs of 60 youth leaders including select CDD staff conducted, to support the development of the curriculum framework and training curricula that provide specific competences for training in YSRHR.
CDD supports the training of 45 male and female youth to cascade youth leadership peer education in SRHR .

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace
SRHR.2 Improved access to contraceptives and medicines
SRHR.2.5. Number of couples protected by various contraceptives over a 1-year period (couple-years protection)

comment.narrative:
1000 young couples reached with family planning and new/increased knowledge on contraceptives.
1000 young couples protected from STTIs via various contraceptives over a 1-year period (couple-years protection).
Means of verification: Leadership change making project reports.

title.narrative: SRHR.4 More respect for the sexual and reproductive rights of groups who are currently denied these rights
SRHR.4.7. Number of key populations reached by communities and advocacy networks with SRHR and HIV/AIDS information

comment.narrative:
2500 young men and women reached by YPEs outreach programmes with SRHR and HIV/AIDS information (directly\*).
Means of verification: project report and beneficiary testimonies.

title.narrative: SRHR.4.8. Number of key populations having received SRHR and HIV/AIDS services

comment.narrative: 45 young men and women received Youth Leadership (peer) Education SRHR including HIV/AID prevention services

title.narrative: III. Organisations key to (sectoral) inclusive development of partner countries are strengthened by inflow of enhanced workforce
III.O.5. % of alumni who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment
III.I.2. % of alumni promoted to more strategic positions within their own organisation or other organisation

comment.narrative: 50 % of the Youth leaders promoted to more strategic positions within their own or other organisations.

title.narrative: III.O.1. % employer satisfaction on suitability of the training for the organisation

comment.narrative:
70% employers of Youth Leadership (peer) training alumni reported satisfaction on suitability of the training for their organisation.
Means of verification: Testimony of health workers and reports by health workers.

title.narrative: III.O.2. % of alumni still employed by the organisation that nominated them

comment.narrative:
80% of alumni still employed by the organisation that nominated them.
Means of verification: testimony of health workers and reports by health workers.

title.narrative: III.I.1. % of alumni who state that they have applied in their workplace the knowledge and skills gained from the interventions

comment.narrative: 80% of the Youth Peer Educators have applied the knowledge and skills gained from the TMT+ in their workplace and through their networks

title.narrative: III.I.3. Narratives from alumni on policy and procedural changes, inclusive development, and innovations as a result of interventions
III.O.4. Testimonials from employers on organisational changes (implemented procedure/techniques, work ethic etc.) due to trained staff (critical mass)
II. Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable
II.P.8. Number of staff of Dutch training education organisations that have gained new insights and ways of working

comment.narrative:
4 staff of Dutch training organisations have gained new insights and ways of working on SRHR issues in developing countries.
ISS-EUR and AFRUGI collaborate to develop joint YPET in other regions.

title.narrative: II.P.1. Number of MoUs or other types of formal collaboration agreements exist 1, 3, 5 years after end of project

comment.narrative:
A signed MoU between EUR-ISS/AFRUGI and CDD that spells out a collaborative relationship beyond the end of the project.
An MoU signed between CDD and Youth Trainers to provide training during the summer school.

title.narrative: II.P.7. Number of Dutch training education organisations that have improved their training methods

comment.narrative:
EUR-ISS & AFRUGI have improved their training methods.
CDD rolls out PET training in its summer school in the three centres supported by ISS/AFRUGI

title.narrative: SRHR.1 Better information and greater freedom of choice for young people about their sexuality
SRHR.1.6. Condom use by young people at last high-risk sex

comment.narrative:
2500 young people (male and female) educated on the use of condoms and evidence gathered on increased use of condoms.
Means of verification: outreach report from 45 peer education trainers.

title.narrative: SRHR.1.2. Number of young people reached with comprehensive, correct information on sexuality, HIV/AIDS, STIs, pregnancy and contraception

comment.narrative: Means of verification: Project report and impact stories from 45 youth peer educators (YPEs)

title.narrative: SRHR.1.4. % of women (20-24yr) who were married or in union before ages 15 and 18

comment.narrative:
The project aims to reduce the number of women (20-24 years old) who were married or in union before ages 15 and 18 by 10%. This may not be translatable as a percentage change.
The project aims to reach 2000 young girls between 15 and 20 with SRHR life skills and education.

title.narrative: SRHR.1.3. Number of health facilities that adopt and implement youth-friendly SRHR and HIV/AIDS services
